description.narrative:
As part of the global trend of shifting and shrinking civic space, we have seen governments and other powerful actors deploy stigmatizing and delegitimizing narratives to undermine the legitimacy of CSOs and civic action. With this initiative, we want to exploreand better understand this dynamic and test the assumption that new narratives can help reinforce and open space for civil society and citizen voice. Where we see civic space being closed, we see specific narratives being used as part of the strategy to shrink the space that civil society, activists, people have to speak out and hold their government to account. This is happening in differentways: we see compelling narratives, which connect to old and deep forms of power, old stories, prejudices and fears, being used to undermine the work of civil society, attack activists and human rights defenders and delegitimize activism in the general population. We see strong, constant, compelling narratives being used to persuade people that the status quo is inevitable, change is not possible and participation is pointless. We are interested in understanding this better and in testing the assumption that if specific narratives are used to close space, can they also be used to open space.
In order to test this we want to develop a proof of conceptthat analyzing dominant narratives and bringing diverse people together at different levels to look at this question will bring us more than looking it alone. We want to test if developing new collectively owned narratives is a worthwhile exercise. And to exploreif we better understand the narrative dimension of civic space can we perhaps eventually also help to create new spaces for dialogue.
We are co-creating a two country pilot initiative to learn and test elements of this hypothesis. One in Niger and one in Uganda.Elements of their approach include: the development of creative communication, development of new stories, giving the issues a human face and calculating the human cost, as well as critical working in coalition building work both develop, spread new narratives and in doing so open new spaces for debate, mobilisation and active citizenship.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib was founded in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Oxfam Novib is member of the Oxfam International confederation. Working together in the confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novib's main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fundraising, campaigning and advocacy. Oxfam Novib’s the Hague office contributes towards this project’s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
